|Title=Know the indications for referring a child to an ophthalmologist.
|Description=None
|Rubric=Management
|Contributors=Elise Launay
|Order=7}}

Refer to ophthalmologist if

* personal or family history: risk factors = ophthalmological examination between 3 and 12 months, even in the absence of warning signs.
* abnormality or doubt on inspection
* abnormality or doubt on screening test
* warning signs
* inability to measure visual acuity (verbal age)

'''IN EMERGENCY if'''

o leukocoria,

o cloudy cornea (glaucoma)

o sudden onset of strabismus

o recent onset of nystagmus

properties.question: Under what circumstances should a child be referred to an ophthalmologist?
properties.option_a: If the child has perfect vision and no family history of eye problems.
properties.option_b: If the child exhibits leukocoria, cloudy cornea, or sudden onset of strabismus or nystagmus.
properties.option_c: If the child prefers to have their eyes examined during a routine check-up.
properties.option_d: If the child has a minor eye irritation that resolves on its own.
